issue.title: priority_queue(first, last) should construct c with (first, last)

discussion.p: Tim's new constructors for priority_queue (LWG ) are specified so that when you construct

blockquote.pre: template<class InputIterator, class Alloc> priority_queue(InputIterator first, InputIterator last, const Alloc& a);
blockquote.p: Effects: Initializes c with first as the first argument, last as the second argument, and a as the third argument, and value-initializes comp; calls make_heap(c.begin(), c.end(), comp).

discussion.p: But the pre-existing constructors are specified so that when you construct

blockquote.pre: template<class InputIterator> priority_queue(InputIterator first, InputIterator last, const Compare& x = Compare(), Container&& y = Container());
blockquote.p: Preconditions: x defines a strict weak ordering ([alg.sorting]).

discussion.p: will default-construct a Container, then move-construct c from that object, then c.insert(first, last), and finally make_heap.
will simply construct c with (first, last), then make_heap.
Also, Corentin's P1425R3 specifies the new iterator-pair constructors for stack and queue to construct c from (first, last). Good.

LWG should refactor the existing constructor overload set so that the existing non-allocator-taking constructors simply construct c from (first, last). This will improve consistency with the resolutions of LWG3506 and P1425, and reduce the surprise factor for users.

resolution.p: This wording is relative to N4878.

pre.ins: template<class InputIterator> priority_queue(InputIterator first, InputIterator last, const Compare& x = Compare());

p.ins: Preconditions: x defines a strict weak ordering ([alg.sorting]).
Effects: Initializes c with first as the first argument and last as the second argument, and initializes comp with x; then calls make_heap(c.begin(), c.end(), comp).

blockquote.p: Preconditions: x defines a strict weak ordering ([alg.sorting]).
Effects: Initializes comp with x and c with y (copy constructing or move constructing as appropriate); calls c.insert(c.end(), first, last); and finally calls make_heap(c.begin(), c.end(), comp).
